image.altText: Daniel Andrews wears a blue suit and white shirt and frowns while looking off camera.

items.synopsis: Victoria's cancellation of the 2026 regional Commonwealth Games is under scrutiny today, as a Senate inquiry holds hearings in Melbourne. Follow live.

title.children: No attempt made to change Victoria's mind after 'emphatic' cancellation, Commonwealth Games inquiry hears

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Geelong Mayor Trent Sullivan is now giving evidence about concerns he says he held from early 2023 about the way the state government was treating local councils during the planning of the Games. He says councils weren't treated as partners and Geelong made official complaints about the pressure being applied and lack of time they were given to make high-level decisions. He says these included a two-day deadline for the council to provide input on the Games planning. "That was the standard that was set going forward for communication for the state government and the City of Greater Geelong," he says. He says Geelong's concerns went unanswered and were proved to be founded when, weeks later, the Games were cancelled. He says he received a phone call from the government 10 minutes before the premier's press conference to announce the cancellation of the games. "It was a blow and it still is a blow to me," Cr Sullivan says. Reporting by Melissa Brown
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Geelong says it lodged official complaint over government's handling of Games planning

children.content: Geelong Mayor Trent Sullivan is now giving evidence about concerns he says he held from early 2023 about the way the state government was treating local councils during the planning of the Games.
He says councils weren't treated as partners and Geelong made official complaints about the pressure being applied and lack of time they were given to make high-level decisions.

props.alt: An aerial view of Kardinia Park.

children.content: Geelong's Kardinia Park was set to host the closing ceremony of the Games.
(Kardinia Park Stadium Trust)
He says these included a two-day deadline for the council to provide input on the Games planning.
"That was the standard that was set going forward for communication for the state government and the City of Greater Geelong," he says.
He says Geelong's concerns went unanswered and were proved to be founded when, weeks later, the Games were cancelled.
He says he received a phone call from the government 10 minutes before the premier's press conference to announce the cancellation of the games.
"It was a blow and it still is a blow to me," Cr Sullivan says.
Reporting by Melissa Brown

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In compiling the initial cost estimates, Mr Yates reveals EY was limited by the state government not providing for consultation with councils, the opportunity to visit sites or have access to design work. Senator Colbeck continues to push the representatives to comment on the final costs (which they weren't involved in providing), or detail an example of another project that had a similar capital cost blow out as the 2026 Commonwealth Games. They say they'll take the question on notice, and cite confidentiality obligations to their clients. Senator Henderson points to a figure in the business case referring to $205 million to $215 million to be provided by the federal government. YATES: That was an assumption that was directly given to us (by the Department of Jobs, Precincts and Regions). HENDERSON: Did the assumption have any basis of fact? YATES: Well, you'd have to ask the department what was the basis of its information … HENDERSON: Well hang on a minute … you're the one preparing the business case, don't you scrutinise the assumptions to be given? Do you ask the question 'was this a committed amount' or 'on what basis are we assuming that we will receive $205 million as a worst case and $215 million as a best case from the federal government?' YATES: That assumption was an assumption that was given to us. HENDERSON: You just take that at face value? You don't query it, you don't question it, you don't say well what's the basis for it? WALKER: We can't answer that question because to do so we might reveal information that's part of cabinet in-confidence. HENDERSON: Oh that's just rubbish! … That is just an absolute cop out. Reporting by Melissa Brown
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Consultants pushed on assumptions included in business case costing

children.content: In compiling the initial cost estimates, Mr Yates reveals EY was limited by the state government not providing for consultation with councils, the opportunity to visit sites or have access to design work.

Senator Colbeck continues to push the representatives to comment on the final costs (which they weren't involved in providing), or detail an example of another project that had a similar capital cost blow out as the 2026 Commonwealth Games.
They say they'll take the question on notice, and cite confidentiality obligations to their clients.
Senator Henderson points to a figure in the business case referring to $205 million to $215 million to be provided by the federal government.
YATES:
That was an assumption that was directly given to us (by the Department of Jobs, Precincts and Regions).
HENDERSON:
Did the assumption have any basis of fact?
YATES:
Well, you'd have to ask the department what was the basis of its information …
HENDERSON:

Well hang on a minute … you're the one preparing the business case, don't you scrutinise the assumptions to be given? Do you ask the question 'was this a committed amount' or 'on what basis are we assuming that we will receive $205 million as a worst case and $215 million as a best case from the federal government?'
YATES:
That assumption was an assumption that was given to us.
HENDERSON:
You just take that at face value? You don't query it, you don't question it, you don't say well what's the basis for it?
WALKER:
We can't answer that question because to do so we might reveal information that's part of cabinet in-confidence.
HENDERSON:
Oh that's just rubbish! … That is just an absolute cop out.
Reporting by Melissa Brown

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Liberal Senator Richard Colbeck has taken up the baton and accused Labor premiers and the media of talking down the games, saying a Western Australia editorial "disgracefully described it as a second-rate sporting event". He's asked the Commonwealth Games Australia representatives how they felt about the descriptions. PHILLIPS: I think for us it's probably a constant battle … in terms of the Commonwealth Games and something we need to work on is that perception of the games. Mr Phillips pointed forward to Gold Coast mayor Tom Tate's appearance in the afternoon, saying he hoped the benefits would be outlined during his evidence. Senator Colbeck said the last three games had all provided an economic benefit and asked whether Alberta, Canada's reference to costs in not bidding for 2030 damaged the image of the Commonwealth Games. "I think it certainly makes our life difficult ," Mr Phillips said. He said Commonwealth Games Australia has to continue to push the cost-benefit ratio, not just the costs. Reporting by Melissa Brown
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Boosting perception of Commonwealth Games 'a constant battle'

children.content: Liberal Senator Richard Colbeck has taken up the baton and accused Labor premiers and the media of talking down the games, saying a Western Australia editorial "disgracefully described it as a second-rate sporting event".
He's asked the Commonwealth Games Australia representatives how they felt about the descriptions.
PHILLIPS:
I think for us it's probably
a constant battle
… in terms of the Commonwealth Games and something we need to work on is that perception of the games.
Mr Phillips pointed forward to Gold Coast mayor Tom Tate's appearance in the afternoon, saying he hoped the benefits would be outlined during his evidence.

Senator Colbeck said the last three games had all provided an economic benefit and asked whether Alberta, Canada's reference to costs in not bidding for 2030 damaged the image of the Commonwealth Games.
"I think
it certainly makes our life difficult
," Mr Phillips said.
He said Commonwealth Games Australia has to continue to push the cost-benefit ratio, not just the costs.
Reporting by Melissa Brown

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Fortescue shares remain under pressure, down 4.3 per cent as the broader market rises. It follows a 23 per cent drop in full year net profit and the shock announcement that the chief executive of its metals business, Fiona Hick, has exited after less than half a year. The boss of Fortesuce Future Industries, the company's newer energy division, Mark Hutchinson, faced questions over the news on an analyst briefing, and revealed the board made the "mutual decision" just yesterday. Here's more from Reuters: The world's fourth-largest iron ore miner, overseen by founder Andrew Forrest as executive chairman, has been beset by senior management turnover over the past two years while its key Iron Bridge project has seen multiple delays and cost overruns. Fortescue has been expanding into green energy and has reorganised into two divisions under energy and metals, with the CEOs of each unit reporting to Forrest and the board. "This organisation does not rely on just one or two people to drive direction," said incoming Fortescue Metals CEO Dino Otranto, who took the helm of the company's iron ore division two years ago and will replace Hick. "I am left with no doubt whatsoever that we have the most amazing team behind this crazy vision that we have got, and we are going to nail it," Otranto said. The decision by Fortescue's board and Hick, who took on the co-CEO role in February, to part ways was made on Sunday. Hick was at a party hosted by Forrest in Western Australia over the weekend to celebrate 20 years in operation, CEO Mark Hutchinson of the firm's energy division confirmed. Hick said in a statement on Monday she valued her experience at Fortescue and would take time to consider her next move. When pressed for more information on Hick's departure on an earnings call, Hutchinson declined to provide further details on the reasons for her exit or around the decision that elevated Otranto to the co-CEO spot. "I do think shareholders deserve a better explanation given that she departed only after five months in the role and also considering the C-Suite changes over the past two to three years," said Goldman Sachs analyst Paul Young on the call. Ian Wells, Fortescue's former chief financial officer, stepped down at the end of January, meaning almost all of the senior executives from a year previous had changed. Executive chairman Andrew Forrest, who has been taking a greater role speaking to stakeholders on results, was absent from the earnings call. "He was not available today," Hutchinson said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Decision for Fortescue Metal CEO to go made yesterday

children.content: Fortescue shares remain under pressure, down 4.3 per cent as the broader market rises.
It follows a 23 per cent drop in full year net profit and the shock announcement that the chief executive of its metals business, Fiona Hick, has exited after less than half a year.

The boss of Fortesuce Future Industries, the company's newer energy division, Mark Hutchinson, faced questions over the news on an analyst briefing, and revealed the board made the "mutual decision" just yesterday.
Here's more from Reuters:

The world's fourth-largest iron ore miner, overseen by founder Andrew Forrest as executive chairman, has been beset by senior management turnover over the past two years while its key Iron Bridge project has seen multiple delays and cost overruns.
Fortescue has been expanding into green energy and has reorganised into two divisions under energy and metals, with the CEOs of each unit reporting to Forrest and the board.

"This organisation does not rely on just one or two people to drive direction," said incoming Fortescue Metals CEO Dino Otranto, who took the helm of the company's iron ore division two years ago and will replace Hick.
"I am left with no doubt whatsoever that we have the most amazing team behind this crazy vision that we have got, and we are going to nail it," Otranto said.

The decision by Fortescue's board and Hick, who took on the co-CEO role in February, to part ways was made on Sunday. Hick was at a party hosted by Forrest in Western Australia over the weekend to celebrate 20 years in operation, CEO Mark Hutchinson of the firm's energy division confirmed.
Hick said in a statement on Monday she valued her experience at Fortescue and would take time to consider her next move.

When pressed for more information on Hick's departure on an earnings call, Hutchinson declined to provide further details on the reasons for her exit or around the decision that elevated Otranto to the co-CEO spot.

"I do think shareholders deserve a better explanation given that she departed only after five months in the role and also considering the C-Suite changes over the past two to three years," said Goldman Sachs analyst Paul Young on the call.
Ian Wells, Fortescue's former chief financial officer, stepped down at the end of January, meaning almost all of the senior executives from a year previous had changed.
Executive chairman Andrew Forrest, who has been taking a greater role speaking to stakeholders on results, was absent from the earnings call.
"He was not available today," Hutchinson said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market remains higher at lunchtime, as markets around the region also climb. The ASX 200 is up by 0.6 per cent, with most sectors on the rise. Major banks are helping push up the broader market, led by a 1 per cent gain for CBA shares. The big miners are mixed, with BHP (+1.2%) and Rio Tinto (+0.9%) both higher but Fortescue (-4.7%) slumping. Around the region, Hong Kong and Tokyo's markets have gained more than 1.5 per cent and stocks in Shanghai have risen more than 2 per cent. Investors were pleased by more policy measures from Beijing, including a reduction in stamp duty on stock trading. In Hong Kong trade, Evergrande shares plunged 80 per cent as they returned to trade after 17 months.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX, Asian markets on the up

children.content: The Australian share market remains higher at lunchtime, as markets around the region also climb.
The ASX 200 is up by 0.6 per cent
, with most sectors on the rise.
Major banks are helping push up the broader market, led by a 1 per cent gain for
CBA
shares.
The big miners are mixed, with
BHP
Rio Tinto
(+0.9%) both higher but
Fortescue
(-4.7%) slumping.
Around the region, Hong Kong and Tokyo's markets have gained more than 1.5 per cent and stocks in Shanghai have risen more than 2 per cent.
Investors were pleased by more policy measures from Beijing, including a reduction in stamp duty on stock trading.
In Hong Kong trade, Evergrande shares plunged 80 per cent as they returned to trade after 17 months.
